text: In this Clare Obscure Expedition 33
guide, I'm going to be going over some
things that I wish I would have known
before I started playing this game and
also some other helpful tips for new
players out there. I would say that this
game is not overly difficult, but it can
be a little bit challenging at the
beginning when you're first figuring out
a lot of mechanics. And there are things
that can just make your life easier if
you know about them rather than finding
out about them halfway through the game
because that did not happen to me at
all. So, the first thing we're going to
discuss in this guide is weaknesses and
resistances. Just about every enemy in
the game has a weakness or multiple
weaknesses or a resistance or multiple
resistances and then other damage types
are kind of neutral. So you always want
to try to be attacking the enemy's
weakness when possible. And if you're
struggling in a fight, you should
consider swapping weapons to a different
weapon or using a skill that does a
different damage type in order to find
the weakness of the enemy. It's it's a
good idea to keep different elements or
different elemental skills across your
team when you go into battle, especially
if you're facing enemies for the first
time and just kind of fumble around
until you stumble upon what the
weaknesses are so you know moving
forward and can deal the most damage to
them. And for this reason as well, it's
good to upgrade more than one weapon for
each character so that you don't have
like a problem when you switch to
another weapon and it's like really low
level and its damage is terrible
compared to the one you're using. So
definitely consider upgrading multiple
elements and try and keep them like
maybe like opposite like a ice one and a
fire one or a light one and a dark one
or something like that or even just you
know a little bit less adjacent like a
light and a fire or whatever something
like that so that you have multiple
damage types of weapons that are
upgraded. So the next thing I want to
discuss is parrying and how important it
is in this game. This is not something
that should be shocking if you play the
demo or if you've played a little bit,
but one tip I really want to give you is
that the parry window for pairing in
this game is not the same as what you
would typically have in a game like this
or in a Souls game, something like that,
where like if you're coming from Kazan
or you're coming from a like Elden Ring
or something, the parry timing is
actually a bit later in this game than
it is in those games. You almost want to
let the attack connect with you before
you parry in order to pull off a parry
rather than trying to parry the instant
the beginning of the attack connects
with you more like you want to be in the
middle of the attack or towards the end
of the attack when you parry. Something
that I found is like holding the button
a little bit when you parry a little bit
longer than you normally would seems to
help as well. So adjust your parry
timing and don't try and parry exactly
when the attack connects with you, but
more of like in the middle of the attack
connecting with you or just that tail
end. Another really important tip is
that Lun has access to a revive skill
that she can get for her kit very early
on in the game, and I highly recommend
getting this skill immediately. And it
might be the easiest way in the game to
beat fights is to keep Luna in your
party and to revive whenever you need to
revive characters. It's not always
possible, like if Luna dies or something
like that, but generally speaking, as
long as she has the skill points and can
throw a revive, you can keep deflecting
and dodging attacks to stay alive until
you can get everyone back up and then
get back into the fight. So Lun's revive
skill is almost a must if you're having
a tough time with this game. If you're
not having a challenging time, then you
don't need it. I didn't use it for
probably like half the game until one of
my colleagues was like, "Oh, by the way,
Luna's revive skill is so OP. It's
making the game super easy." And I was
like, "She has a revive skill." So, it's
definitely very good. And if you're
having a tough time, particularly if
you're playing on like the hardest
difficulty, make sure you have that
skill. So, the next thing worth noting
is something that I figured it out
because I had like a bug or two that I
had to like reload in order to prevent
uh a scenario where I couldn't progress
is that even though the game only has
one save file in the sense that like
when you load into the game, when you go
to load up your game when you first
start it, you can only pick that that
one playthrough or another playthrough
from a different character, another
playthrough, like there isn't multiple
save slots for that that playthrough
that you can reload. There is a load
previous saves from the menu while
you're still in the game. So, like if
you if you get in a situation where like
you made a decision, you wish you could
undo it or you messed something up and
you want to go back, if you hit escape
and go or go to the menu and find load
previous saves, there are like a handful
of previous saves that you can reload in
order to backtrack a little ways and be
able to undo a mistake that you made.
So, make sure you use that if you need
it. So, let's talk a little bit about
Picto next and which ones are good early
on. Typically, early on in the game,
what you're focused on is two things.
dealing the most damage as you can and
getting as many action points as you can
so that you can use more skills. In the
beginning of the game, you don't have as
many ways to gain action points, so
you're basic attacking a lot, but you
want to change that by getting action
points. So, look for pictos with action
points and look for pictos that are
going to boost your damage. Now, as you
get further and further into the game,
you'll start to realize that the passive
bonuses on your pictos become more and
more important. And once that starts
happening, you're going to have to keep
like changing your pictos out to get
higher and higher stats. And health is a
very, very valuable one because the
thing about health is it makes sure that
you stay alive and it lets you put your
points into, you know, whatever your
weapons scale with. And also, there's a
lot of effects that heal you based on
your max health. So the higher your max
health is, the more they heal you. And
obviously, the more hits you can absorb
in combat. And the more hits you can
absorb, the more you can learn attack
patterns of enemies before you wipe, so
that when you go into a fight next time,
you understand the attack pattern a bit
better and you have a better chance of
survival. The next thing I want to talk
a little bit about is multi-hit attacks
and attacks with less hits. Early on in
the game, you have a damage cap at 9,999
damage, meaning you cannot deal more
than that no matter what you do. And so
once you get about a third of the way of
the game or so, you're going to start
realizing that the damage that you're
dealing is capped from that in a way
that mult it skews you towards multi-hit
attacks because multi-hit attacks, if
they all deal 9,999 damage, comes out to
be more damage than if you do a onehit
attack that does that. So you want to be
on the lookout for skills that do multi
hits early on in the game. And later on
in the game, you'll be able to lift that
damage cap. So know that. and then it
kind of balances out and you can use
whatever you like. But early on, pay
attention to multi-hit attacks. And
also, because multi-hit attacks have a
chance to crit for each attack that they
do, if you have effects that trigger on
crit, the more attacks you do, the more
likely you're going to get crits that
will trigger those effects. So, they're
just generally better as a whole. This
doesn't mean that every skill is better,
but generally, you're going to want to
look for multi-hit attacks, especially
early on. The next thing I want to
mention is use your tints. You can use
your energy tints, your healing tints,
your revive tints, especially your
revive tints. Especially if you don't
have Luna in your party. These all
replenish whenever you rest at a
checkpoint. So, these are not like, oh,
I used my revive, now I don't have any.
Like, they will replenish each time you
get to a checkpoint. So, make sure you
use them in between checkpoints. Like,
they're there to be used. If you need to
heal, heal. If you need to revive,
revive or whatever. You can only use
these in combat, though. You can't use
them outside of combat. So, make sure
that you use them while you're in combat
if you need them. The next thing, which
I think you will probably figure out,
but in case you don't, is that burn is
really OP in this game because burn can
stack up. I don't even know what the max
stacks of burn is. I've seen like 500
stacks of burn on an enemy before, but I
don't know what the actual cap is. But
what this does is it deals damage to
that target when it's their turn for
like three turns, I think, by default.
And there are a lot of skills that stack
up burn. There's a lot of ways to
increase the amount of burn damage you
deal as well as the number of stacks you
apply when you're doing skills. And this
can be a really good way to stack up a
lot of damage. And it will still deal
damage even if your character is dead,
right? Like like if the character that
stacks damage up or burn up on the enemy
dies when it's that enemy's turn again,
even if that character's dead, the
damage is still going to happen. So
that's really really strong. So be on
the lookout for characters and skills
that do burn or weapons that do burn
early on. Yeah. And another thing that's
really important to have in your party
as well, particularly as you get to
about a third of the way through the
game, is characters that can deal with
shields effectively. There are some
skills in the game, particularly like
the one that Myel has called breaking
rules, that will just remove the shields
from the target and deal damage anyway.
And there are some other skills that
will just go through shields, etc. So,
you want to make sure you have a good
way of dealing with shields so that you
don't just waste all your AP trying to
burn a shield down and then do a base
attack. So, keep my eye around or find
another skill from someone else that can
deal with shields. And the last thing
I'll just say is that you have varied
attributes that you can select to level
your characters up and you can respspec.
And what I found is that as you move
through the game, because the weapons
that you're going to be using scale with
different stats as you go and because
they have different levels until you
upgrade them, putting points in stats
that deal damage isn't necessarily the
greatest strategy. Cuz if you have like
all these points in agility and then you
pick a defense scaling weapon or
something and now you have to move them
all to defense and then you move from
defense to a luck scaling weapon, now
you have to move them. You can only
respec so many times. You have a limited
number of items. So basically what I
found works best is early on at least
putting a lot of points in vitality and
maybe some luck for critical chance. Um,
agility, vitality, and luck are
generally, in my opinion, the best stats
because vitality keeps you alive, allows
you to learn attack patterns, and again,
as I mentioned, there are effects that
scale off your max HP, and this
increases it the most. Agility increases
your speed. Even if you don't um if it's
not scaling with your weapon, it
increases your speed so that you can go
faster, you can go more often in combat,
allowing you to control combat in a lot
of cases. And then luck increases your
critical chance. And there are a lot of
effects that are based off critical. So
that's really strong. In an ideal world,
you would probably have weapons that
scale off two of those three stats.
Defense is also not a bad stat. It's
just it doesn't affect the uh the things
that affect your max health or rec give
you a percentage of your max health the
way that vitality does. So I think
vitality generally is a bit better. And
might will increase your damage if you
do reach the stat caps which are 99. But
I don't think most people are going to
need that. And even if you could, um,
you're still probably better off putting
your extra points in vitality so that
you don't like get one shot every time
you're at the end of the game. So, that
wraps up some tips to help you guys out
early on. I hope these were useful for
you. I'm going to have character guides
as well, kind of going through the
mechanics of each character, the weapons
of each character, the skills of each
character, what I think you should do
for stats on each character with pictos
and luminous for those characters. So,
if you're looking for a more specific
guide on a specific character, be sure
to check those out. But if you're just
looking for a little general help before
you get started and you'll figure the
rest out on your own, that's what this
video is really meant for. As always, if
you have other tips for other players,
maybe things I forgot to mention, maybe
you're playing and I forgot to mention
something or you have other questions,
maybe something I didn't answer here but
you're confused about, let me know in
the comments and I will try and answer
it as soon as I can. Oh, and before I
forget, one last thing. If you do not
like QTE or at some point in the game
you get tired of having to do QTE on all
of your skills, you can go to the
accessibility options of the game and
turn off or basically turn on automatic
QTE so that you don't have to do them
anymore. The game will just
automatically nail them for you and you
can remove that from the game.
[Music]
